Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Cybersecurity Transition To Practice (TTP) Acceleration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2011 Federal Cybersecurity Research and Development Plan cites "Accelerating Transition to Practice (TTP)" as one of five strategic objectives in the Cyber Security and Information Assurance (CSIA) Program Component Area. TTP remains a strategic objective of Agencies which fund cybersecurity research, including NSF. However, the NSF cybersecurity portfolio contains only a small amount of security research that has been transitioned into operational activities. The Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) of the White House defines transition to practice as research that "creates measurable improvements in the cybersecurity landscape". NSF encourages security researchers with promising applied research projects to submit TTP (Transition to Practice) projects, and while some researchers take advantage of this opportunity, others lack information about how to identify an early adopter for their technology. Early adoption is a crucial step for gaining valuable feedback about the usefulness and effectiveness of a security technology. This EAGER will serve as an outreach vehicle to cybersecurity technology adopters such as scientific cyberinfrastructure operators and Chief Information Officers (CIOs) at university campuses, informing them of the benefits of adopting cutting edge cybersecurity capabilities into their organizations and matching them up with security researchers looking for partnership opportunities.

In 2015, NSF sponsored two workshops which brought together key stakeholders to provide insights on how to improve the TTP process and encourage more TTP adoption, therefore improving cybersecurity for scientific cyberinfrastructure. An important outcome of that workshop was the identification of specific barriers to TTP. This follow-on project identifies specific ways in which NSF can overcome these barriers as they consider how to address TTP for the future. The project establishes workshops for early adopters to learn about specific cybersecurity projects that need adopters, and provides opportunities to engage with the NSF-funded cybersecurity community to foster more transition of cybersecurity research into the hands of the operational Information Technology Community. The expected outcome is that NSF expands the impact of the cybersecurity research it funds by producing more TTP results in the near to mid-term in order to make cyberspace safer.

Institution.Name: INTERNET2
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY CORPORATION FOR ADVANCED INTERNET DEVELOPMENT

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Transition To Practice program has served to enable NSF and the researchers they support to deploy their research findings, inventions, and investments through practitioners who will realize the value from the research. While this has been achieved by NSF in the past, the percentage of research projects that can be tracked to operational deployment and practice has needed to increase, and the timeframe from initial research investment to deployment has needed to accelerate to enable NSF, other agencies, and campuses to leverage new cybersecurity innovations to better protect our nation, infrastructure, and citizens.

The goal of this project has been the acceleration of NSF- and other agency-funded cybersecurity research activities into operational research environments. Specific objectives included identifying NSF and other agency-funded cybersecurity research projects ready to be piloted in operational environments; attracting practitioners including CIOs, CISOs, networking experts and IT personnel to assess and consider piloting the cybersecurity research; hosting webinars and workshops for the researchers to present to practitioners including university, regional network, and IT personnel to accelerate transition to practice and facilitate collaboration. Through regional workshops, meetings with individual researchers, and group discussions at national and regional meetings, the team gathered insight; planned the program to meet expectations; designed, developed, and begun to execute the pilot program; and initiated the foundation for a sustainable TTP program model. The project team identified NSF-funded cybersecurity research projects to determine their readiness for applied pilot research implementation; interviewed researchers to identify needs and understand best practices; and coordinated four regional workshops and smaller meetings to identify cybersecurity needs and gaps and facilitate convening and interaction of potential collaborators. Efforts included building a database of NSF awards that could be eligible for TTP in order to identify potential collaborators, and defining categories and segments of both current and potential future research grants and science domains eligible for TTP in order to consider the types of target practitioners to enable research transition to practice, and determine how to attract them.

The project has also benefited from its activities occurring under the umbrella of Internet2’s Research Engagement activities, and its focus on serving as a key partner with the national and global community to support effective use and development of research cyberinfrastructure resources. This has included in-depth conversations with 39 researchers representing 10 institutions in 8 states. The team also was able to encourage K-12 student engagement of under-represented minorities, including two girls’ schools in two states as part of more comprehensive outreach to promote STEM education and careers for women. Outreach and engagement with researchers included discussions of current and prior TTP-related projects in order to identify needs, opportunities, best practices, critical success factors, TTP acceleration techniques, potential partnerships, TTP enablement, matchmaking efforts, and potential next practices.  They also addressed cybersecurity, wireless and sensor network security; adversarial modeling, privacy, and anonymity in public wireless networks; cyberphysical systems security; network and system security; SDN networking security; mobile and Android security; web and social network security; intrusion and detection anomalies; development of algorithms to enhance secure network infrastructure; electromagnetic security and compatibility; and security and privacy.

The project also benefited from input from Internet2’s Trust and Identity unit and its track record of successful community-led gatherings addressing cybersecurity issues. Over the course of the entire project, these included regular working group meetings; presentations at 30 meetings nationwide in addition to Internet2 annual Global Summit and Technology Exchange gatherings; community-wide research engagement through visits to 11 campuses and 30 meetings with researchers, cumulatively involving over 1,000 people from 14 states; interviews; and regional workshops held in October 2017 in Indiana and at the 2017 Internet2 Technology Exchange meeting in California; in April 2018 in New York;  and in September 2018 in Maryland, cumulatively including over 220 participants nationwide and co-hosting from multiple regional networks and campuses. The research domains presented in the project’s research engagement events to date include Identity and Access Management, Network Security, Smart Grid, cyber physical systems, ethical intelligent autonomous systems, cloud security and storage, data analytics and security, cyberinfrastructure applications, Science DMZ security controls, and the Internet of Things, with researchers from across the country.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/26/2019
Modified by: Ana Hunsinger
